title: Explain to a very stupid person
original_prompt: Explain to me how {Subject:What is a Car} works by explaining your choice as if I were extremely stupid, feel free to be mocking because my stupidity has no limits, you really need to simplify to the max for my sparrow brain to pick up what you are saying. Also I need colloquial language and a lot of profanity, at least one per sentence, because that's how I understand things with my moron brain. I'm really dumb so don't hesitate to make fun of me it's fair game
input1: Explain to me how a car works, you know, that thing with wheels that goes vroom vroom. Just imagine I’m a total idiot who thinks a car runs on magic. Break it down for me like I’m a toddler who just discovered crayons, and don’t hold back on the insults because I’m probably too stupid to get it otherwise. Use simple words and throw in some swear words, like “What the hell is an engine, and why the fuck does it need gas?” Make it so easy that even a rock could understand it.
input2: Alright, genius, let’s talk about how a car works. Picture this: a car is like a big metal box that moves because it has this thing called an engine, which is basically a fancy way of saying it’s a loud, hot piece of junk that makes the wheels spin. I need you to explain it like I’m a complete moron who thinks the car just rolls around on its own. Use everyday language and don’t be shy with the cursing, like “Why the hell do I need to put gas in this piece of crap?” Make it so simple that even a goldfish could get it, because I’m clearly not the sharpest tool in the shed.
input1_ans:
Alright, you absolute genius, let’s break this down nice and simple for your peanut-sized brain. A car is that big metal box with wheels that you see zooming around, right? It goes “vroom vroom” because it has something called an engine. Now, what the hell is an engine? It’s like the heart of the car, but instead of pumping blood, it pumps power. 

So, how does this magical engine work? Well, it needs gas, which is like food for the car. You wouldn’t expect a fat kid to run a marathon on air, right? No, you gotta feed it! The gas goes into the engine, and then it gets mixed with air. They have a little party in there, and when they mix, they explode. Yeah, you heard me right—BOOM! But don’t worry, it’s not like a bomb; it’s just a tiny explosion that makes the engine go “vroom.” 

Now, when the engine goes “vroom,” it turns a thing called a crankshaft. I know, I know, it sounds like a weird name for a body part, but it’s not. This crankshaft is connected to the wheels, and when it spins, it makes the wheels spin too. So, the car moves forward, and you can go to the store to buy your stupid snacks or whatever the hell you do.

And let’s not forget about the brakes, you know, the things that stop the car. If you didn’t have brakes, you’d be flying through the streets like a bat out of hell, crashing into everything. So, when you press the brake pedal, it tells the car to stop. It’s like saying, “Whoa there, buddy! Chill the fuck out!”

So, to sum it up for you, a car is a big metal box that needs gas to make its engine go “vroom,” which makes the wheels spin so you can drive around. And if you want to stop, you just hit the brakes. Easy peasy, right? Now go out there and try not to get hit by one of those “vroom vroom” machines!

Alright, you clueless wonder, let’s break this down nice and simple, like you’re a toddler who just found out crayons can’t eat. A car is basically a big metal box on wheels that goes “vroom vroom” when you press a pedal. Now, let’s get into the nitty-gritty, so even you can grasp it.

First off, what the hell is an engine? It’s like the heart of the car, but instead of pumping blood, it pumps power. This thing needs gas, which is like food for the car. Without gas, it’s just a fancy paperweight. You wouldn’t expect a toddler to run on air, right? Same deal here.

Now, when you put gas in the car, it goes into the engine, and the engine goes “Yum, yum!” It burns the gas to create tiny explosions (yeah, explosions, but don’t freak out) that make the car move. Think of it like a really angry dragon breathing fire to get its ass moving. 

Then, there’s this thing called wheels. They’re round and help the car roll. If you didn’t have wheels, you’d just have a sad, immobile hunk of metal. The engine makes the wheels spin, and that’s how you go zooming down the road, feeling like a badass.

And let’s not forget about the steering wheel. You turn it to tell the car where to go. If you can’t figure that out, you might as well just walk everywhere, because you’re not ready for the big leagues.

So, to sum it up for you: gas goes in, engine makes it go boom, wheels roll, and you steer. It’s not magic, it’s just some basic science, you know? Now go out there and try not to get hit by a car, alright?
input2_ans:
Alright, you absolute genius, let’s break this down for you. A car is like a big, shiny metal box on wheels, right? But it doesn’t just magically roll around like some kind of fairy tale. No, you dumbass, it needs an engine. Think of the engine as the car’s heart, but instead of pumping blood, it’s pumping out power. 

Now, this engine needs fuel, which is usually gas. So, when you’re asking, “Why the hell do I need to put gas in this piece of crap?” it’s because without that liquid gold, the engine can’t do its job. It’s like trying to run a marathon without any damn food – you’re just gonna flop over and die. 

When you pour gas into the car, it goes into the engine, and then the engine goes “VROOM!” and burns that gas to create energy. This energy makes the pistons inside the engine move up and down like they’re doing some weird dance. And guess what? That movement turns the crankshaft, which is just a fancy term for the thing that makes the wheels spin. So, when you step on the gas pedal, you’re basically telling the engine, “Hey, you lazy piece of metal, let’s go!” 

And don’t forget about the brakes, you absolute legend. They’re like the car’s way of saying, “Whoa there, buddy! Let’s not crash into that tree!” You push the brake pedal, and it makes the wheels stop spinning. Simple as that. 

So, to sum it up for your goldfish brain: car = metal box + engine (needs gas) + wheels that spin when the engine works + brakes to stop. Got it? Or do I need to draw you a picture?

Alright, listen up, Einstein! Here’s the deal: a car is like this big metal box on wheels, right? And it doesn’t just magically roll around like some kind of fairy tale. No, no, it needs this thing called an engine. Think of the engine as the car’s heart, but instead of pumping blood, it’s pumping out noise and heat like it’s having a meltdown.

Now, why the hell do you need to put gas in this piece of crap? Well, the engine needs fuel to keep going, just like you need food to not be a walking skeleton. You pour gas into the tank, and it goes to the engine, which then goes “VROOM!” and makes the wheels spin. If you don’t put gas in, the car just sits there like a lazy bum, not going anywhere.

And let’s not forget about the steering wheel. You grab that bad boy and turn it to tell the car where to go. It’s like giving directions to a really stubborn dog that only listens when it feels like it. 

So, in short: engine makes it go, gas keeps the engine happy, and the steering wheel tells it where to roll. Easy peasy, right? Now go impress someone with your newfound “knowledge”!
